content: ridge knitwise ridge 1 k1 join k1 ridge 2 kf&b join k2 3 sts ridge 3 k2 join k2 ridge 4 kf&b k1 join k3 4 sts ridge 5 k2 w&t k2 ridge 6 kf&b k2 join k4 5 sts ridge 7 k4 join k4 ridge 8 kf&b k3 join k5 6 sts the instructions for the next eight ridges are on the following page so as to keep them all together … 4 ridge 9 k5 join k5 ridge 10 kf&b k4 join k6 7sts ridge 11 k5 w&t k5 ridge 12 kf&b k5 join k7 8sts ridge 13 k7 join k7 ridge 14 kf&b k6 join k8 9sts ridge 15 k8 join k8 ridge 16 kf&b k7 join k9 10 sts from now on it gets easier - honestly first you can use the cast on tail of yarn to close that short seam in the starting circle you ll now be working in rounds so you need to mark the start of the first round with a safety pin after the last ridge worked do this after the first couple of ridges i know a spiral doesn t actually have rounds but for the purposes of this pattern we need to impose rounds on it first round ridge 1 k8 w&t k8 ridge 2 k9 join k9 repeat these two ridges all round the circle until you get back to your safety pin alternating short ridges and joined ones helps the circle to lay flat - after a fashion 5 plain rounds from now on you can forget about those shaping short ridges as the rest of the rounds are worked without them to make the knitting curve into something more hat shaped so … work every ridge as a plain joining ridge k9 join k9 move your safety pin over to the new outside ridge to mark the start and end of each round after the first of these plain rounds the knitting will look a bit like a bowl it will look more like a hat with every plain round you complete i worked three plain rounds for this hat to allow for a folded brim this is where the plain rounds start as the knitting is a spiral you will need to work a tapering strip of knitting after your last plain round to give the hat a smooth edge 6 finishing it off for a long gradual tapered edge decreasing ridges are inserted after every five normal joined ridges like this ridges 1 -
